file_content.text: Well, if it isn't the new Commander. It's a pleasure to be able to work with you again, sir. Your work at Kuat was impressive, to say the least.
It's been a long time, Admiral Aygo.
That it has! I really do wish we had more time to catch up, but the Eternal Empire's not sitting around, so neither can we.
If only it was as easy to send the Eternal Empire packing as you did those Imps back on Kuat.
I don't remember you.
Well, that bruises my ego a bit, but considering everything you've been tied up in--not to mention the years in stasis--can't say I really blame you.
I'm Admiral Bey'wan Aygo. We fought together at the Battle of Kuat. You really helped us out of a bad spot, and wow did you really send those Imps packing.
Err.... Sorry sir, that remark was totally inappropriate, given our current alliance.
[Flash a knowing smirk]
That kind of carelessness jeopardizes everything we're trying to build here.
You're entirely correct, Commander. I won't let it happen again.
[Lower your voice] Those Imps really had it coming.
Heheh... Didn't they, though?
At any rate, my job is to coordinate the Alliance's military and strategic intelligence assets, and I'm looking forward to working with you to enhance our military capacity.
Sir. Welcome to your Alliance's military headquarters. Pleasure to have you here.
Likewise, Admiral. I look forward to working together.
I'm relieved to hear it, Commander.
[Agent Background] Aygo... You were a Fleet Admiral at the Battle of Kuat.
Hmph. I was. You were there too. You and that Admiral Ranken did quite a number on our forces.
It doesn't quite sound like it's a pleasure to you.
Forgive me, Commander. We've been on the opposite side of a war for a lot of years... old habits.
You know, I've never really liked Bothans....
I can't believe we're trusting our military command to a Republic officer.
Yeah well I've never really liked Imps either, so I guess we're kinda even there.
But that's all the past--it has to be.
We've got the Eternal Empire out there now, and it's going to take all of us working together to even have a chance of stopping them.
My job here is to coordinate the Alliance's military and strategic intelligence assets.
That said, we're too small to accomplish much right now. We're going to need to start by growing, which includes both recruitment, and securing additional materiel.
Let me know if and when you're looking to help, we've got plenty of work to go around.
Hello, Commander. How can I help you?
How are things going here, Admiral?
What sorts of things can I do to help the effort here?
That's all, Admiral.
Understood.
It's pretty simple, really. We need what any war effort needs: minds and materiel.
While you're out in the field, keep an eye out for noteworthy recruits--candidates with experience in command, or specialists with any military or intelligence background.
Beyond that, we need war supplies, and lots of them. I'll take anything you've got on hand that you're willing to part with.
I'll be blunt, Commander: We've got an awful lot of work ahead of us.
We're just starting to wrap our heads around this entire alliance, and smoothing over the old rivalries.
We're going to need to fill out our command structure, and buy, borrow, or steal a lot more hardware before we can mount any sort of credible operations.
I'm hoping you'll be able to lend us a hand in getting off the ground.
[Turn in Military Equipment] I've got some equipment for you, Admiral.
Outstanding, Commander. I'll see it put to good use.
[Turn in More Military Equipment]
[Back]
Good day, Commander.
Commander, I just wanted to say excellent job in recruiting Zenith.
The man is a master of tactical sabotage, has a lifetime of experience leading underground resistance movements, and he's well accustomed to working under resource limitations.
He's not much for conversation, though.
Hmph. It's true, his type rarely are. That kind of life tends to leave its mark. There's no arguing about his skills, though.
It seemed like the exact skillset we need.
I could not agree with you more.
Zenith has already drawn up proposals for additional resistance operations across several worlds.
At any rate, I should get back to it, Commander. Again, though, great work on this one.
He's a terrorist.
Nobody ever said war was pretty, Commander... and underground resistance can be a particularly messy business.
The line between terrorist and resistance fighter gets real thin real fast sometimes, but Zenith is on our side on this one. He has skills and knowledge we need.
Ah, Commander. I was just reading up on your newest recruit, Rusk. Excellent job in bringing him in.
A brilliant soldier according to his records. First to volunteer for impossible missions, and somehow always gets the job done.
He's certainly no stranger to being in the thick of it on the front line, or even behind it a lot of the time--his units have had high casualty rates.
[Trooper Background] Sounds like someone who could have been prime material for Havoc squad.
He's used to risks and does what it takes to get the job done. He's exactly what we need.
Maybe we could set him up as a SpecForce officer, have him train up the more talented volunteers.
I question his ability to work alongside Imperials. He's holding on to old grudges.
I understand the concern, Commander, but there's nothing like necessity and a larger threat for bringing old enemies together.
[Say Nothing]
[Imperial Background] But only until that threat is gone.
Well, I guess we'll just cross that bridge when we come to it, won't we Imp?
At any rate, I should get back to it, Commander. Just wanted to say good job on this one.
Commander, I just wanted to say thank you for speaking to Oggurobb and getting him to see reason.
Oggurobb will be giving me a stink eye for a week over this, but it's worth it. Lokin's experience, knowledge, and contacts make him utterly invaluable here.
I understand Lokin knows a lot about biology, genetics, and whatnot... but splitting his time with research duty would have really undermined our work here.
You've made the right decision, Commander. Thanks again.
Commander. That C2 droid just did something kind of amazing. He's modified the food processors in our barracks, and now everything they're making is nutritionally optimized.
Some of the troops might complain a bit, but this will be great for keeping our forces in fit fighting shape. If you see that droid, thank him for me.
Hey, Commander... that C2 unit has started dropping off crates of packed meals in the barracks. I'm not really sure what's gotten into it, but it's not really helpful.
The meals aren't going to last in the field like our standard rations, and there's not really enough here to feed an army anyhow. Could you ask it to stop?
Commander, we either need to talk some sense into that protocol droid or just turn it off. It's carpeted the barracks in pillows!
Not to mention it's swapped the padding on just about every seat it could find to ultra-plush... stuff. It's not really appropriate for military quarters.
Sir, you care to tell me why my command room smells like some parlor in the red light sector? Ugh....
This has to be that protocol droid's doing. Make it stop--please.
Commander. Oggurobb just sent me a holo, claiming you've authorized a dual assignment for Lokin. That he'll be spending half his time in the Research Lab. Tell me the Hutt is making this up.
He's already called you about it? I've never seen a Hutt do anything that fast in my life.
I understand he knows a lot about genetics and whatnot, but splitting his time with research work's going to really undermine us here.
He's not making it up. I think the Research Lab should have equal access to Lokin's expertise.
[Close Discussion] Those are my orders as commander and I expect you to follow them.
Understood, Commander, it's your call to make.
If there's nothing else, I'll be getting back to work.
C'mon, Commander, I'm serious.
[Confirm Decision] I thought people in the Republic loved sharing and compromise? To think Oggurobb would be a better Rep than you...
You son of a... Rgh! Shoulda known better than to try reasoning with an Imp...
What was that, Admiral?
Nothing at all, Commander! Must be your Imp paranoia acting up again.
[Ignore the remark]
If you'll excuse me, I'm going to get back to being productive...
[Confirm Decision] I understand, Admiral, but Lokin's got talents useful to both you and Oggurobb. It's only fair that we give the lab equal access to Lokin's time.
[Reverse Decision] Okay, you've convinced me. You can keep Lokin assigned here full time.
Commander, there you are. What happened with Lokin?
We had a disagreement. He attacked me and then ran off.
Lokin turned out to be more of a monster than I thought. We're better off without him.
Mmh. A shame we won't have access to his intel, but I trust your judgement.
Wonder if we'll ever run into him again down the road. There're a whole lot of stars out there, but the Galaxy seems like a smaller place every day.
Bah, I'm just babbling. Don't let me waste your time, Commander.
Wow. Enough of a monster that even an Imp says he's not worth it. Sounds like you made the right call, Commander. Oh, um... no offense intended.
Ah, a shame. Would have loved to have access to his intel, but it sounds like he was too unstable to be worthwhile.
Don't worry, we'll find others.
[Innocent Look] That's not normal for Republic military housing?
[Say Nothing]
Maybe the droid figured soft pillows are perfect for you soft Pub soldiers?
Least we don't spend more time killing each other than the enemy. Maybe you'd actually win a war for once.
Hghh.
[Say nothing]
He's a great soldier, but be careful about giving him command. I think he's reckless--the type to take unnecessary risks. His record seems to prove it.
Hmm. Noted. Maybe we set him up as an officer and have him train some of our better volunteers. Apply his experience without risking his battlefield decision making.
[Smirk] It does lead to you working with all kinds of interesting people, doesn't it?
Hmph. That it does.
Qyzen Fess: fearless warrior, renowned hunter, expert survivalist, and respected as a leader amongst his people.
By itself, word that Qyzen is working with us will give us huge inroads with most any Trandoshan clan out there.
Not to mention the Ex-Warstalkers Qyzen's bringing with him. They'll be a powerful addition to our forces.
We have to keep a close eye on the Ex-Warstalkers that have come with him, though. They used to fight for the Dread Masters.
I agree entirely. In fact, I've already had the lot scheduled for regular psych evaluations to be sure. I don't think it'll be an issue though.
It was mainly Kephess that the Dread Masters had control over. Most of the Warstalkers were freely following his strength.
Hmh. We've got ourselves a Trandoshan hero leading some of the strongest Trandoshan forces this galaxy's ever seen. Pretty good day in my book, Commander.
Absolutely, Commander. Still, just to be sure, I've arranged psych check-ups for all of them, considering their background with the Dread Masters.
I don't think the Ex-Warstalkers he's bringing with him will be all that useful, though. They were crushed on Denova.
With respect, Commander, I couldn't disagree more. The Warstalkers were among the most effective and respected merc units in the galaxy. They never lost a fight before Denova.
The Warstalkers lost because the Dread Masters compromised their command and forced some pretty big mistakes.
Which reminds me, I should arrange regular psych check-ups for all of them. Can't be too careful.
I guess none of that's news to you though, considering the extensive history the two of you have together.
He's even respected by the Jedi Order. Not many Trandoshans get invited into the Jedi Temple on Tython just to catch up with old friends.
Commander. Is Rusk with you?
No--we don't need a slaver in the Alliance. His unit of "convicts" weren't actually convicted, so much as forcibly drafted off the streets.
That's... horrible! I had no idea. In fact, I'm going to report it. I've still got a lot of friends on Coruscant who can get to the bottom of this.
Also, I'll try to screen my information more carefully in the future.
It got complicated. He pulled a blaster on me--I won.
He was about to shoot an old crew mate, and I wasn't about to let it happen. Got a new recruit for Hylo out of it, though.
He was reckless, and couldn't see reason. We're better off without him.
I see. I'm sorry to hear that, but it seems like you made the right call. We'll look elsewhere.
I see. Sorry to hear that. At least you got an old crewmate back--I'm sure Hylo will appreciate the help.
Back so soon... I take it things didn't go so well.
Not at all. He more or less cut comms as soon as he saw who I was, but not before threatening to kill me when I least expect it.
Bah, I was afraid it might go down this way. Oh well, nothing to be done about it. Like I said, if he can't handle working alongside Imperials, there's no point in bringing him in.
He did not react very well to my bringing up Balmorra. In hindsight, that may have been a mistake.
Yeah... I probably shouldn't have brought up Balmorra....
No, it didn't. He basically saw me, said he'd kill me when I least expect it, and then cut comms.
Zenith made it pretty clear that he's not going to work with Imperials.
I made one small joke. Zenith blew up and threatened to kill me.
Come on, I warned you about this! Did you even read the alert I sent you?
We've made a good start, Commander, but it's proving to be a lot harder than we thought to the merge Imperial and Republic forces. Differences in 'Command Philosophy'.
For example, I just had to remind a certain Imperial Officer that it's unacceptable to open fire on a friendly fighter craft because it's failed a patrol maneuver.
That's terrible. We're short enough on soldiers and craft as it is.
Something obvious to the two of us, but not to this one. Dunno how much more of this depravity I can take.
What a waste. Should have let the craft return and then just shot the pilot.
Ugh. Forgot who I was talking to for a second....
Nothing inspires quite like fear.
Long story short, Commander: we're getting there, and we'll figure it out. You keep bringing in the allies and equipment, we'll be off the ground in no time.
[Say Nothing]
If you can't figure out how to work with old enemies, how can you ask everyone else to?
You're right, sir.... We have to learn how to make this work, and it starts with leadership.
I'm happy to say that things are starting to come together a bit, Commander.
Our forces have all been training together for a while now. There's an incident here or there, but the old rivalries are pretty well smoothed over.
All the equipment you've been securing for us also has morale up, too. Nothing brightens your day like new set of cutting edge hardware.
Keep bringing it in, Commander. We're going to be mounting our first operations soon. We'll need everything and everyone we can get.
We've come a long way, Commander.
It was not easy, but after all the training and cooperation, we've finally got everyone feeling more like they're part of a unified alliance force, rather than a bunch of cobbled factions.
We're trained, equipped, and we've got ourselves the makings of what I dare call a small fleet.
Sure, we can't take the Eternal-Fleet head-on, but we are mounting our own tactical operations. Initial results have been very encouraging, and fantastic for morale.
Things are only going to scale up from here, Commander. You keep bringing us everything you can find, we'll put every scrap to good use.
You have my sympathy, Admiral. I know this isn't easy.
Wow, that's pretty rough. Hang in there, Admiral.
